subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Macbeth
msgSnippet: Thanks, Rick. You caught me on HOz ; Spellcheckers don t work in Shavian!  Glad you liked the file.  Nice job on the bookmark.  I feel your pain with spacing,
messageBody:
Thanks, Rick.
 
You caught me on HOz ; Spellcheckers don't work in Shavian!  Glad you liked the file.  Nice job on the bookmark.  I feel your pain with spacing, etc.  Never could get Jerome to work quite right with the half-letters in some font sizes in some programs.  There;s a thing called kerning, whcih some editors can help a bit with, recognizing for instance that more space is needed between different letter pairs.
 
> I also understand the need for artsy lettering for special
> occasions... but believe there is a real use for a more
legible
> version of quickscript closer to your original. 
 
Very true.  I hope you and others take up the ball and run with it. Let cursive and discrete scripts flourish. And though I enjoy handwriting better in the former, I definitely prefer reading and typing the latter!
 
Please don't be disappointed (if you are) about the retroversion!  jM  hAv  dun wel, jaN  skFwykx !
 
 
Shalom v'Tovah,
 
Jon  
http://surf.to/frimmin
 
It is more necessary to love much than to think much;
always do that which impels you most to love.
 
        --St. Teresa of Avila, The Interior Castle
----- Original Message -----
From: "geoflyfisher" <geoflyfisher@...>
To: <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, February 26, 2002 9:57 PM
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Macbeth

> Jon,
>
> Thanks for the comments...  I just read
(and printed for my office) a
> copy of the pretty Lord's Prayer. 
It is beautiful... (by the way,
> did you mean <Hos> for
"those"?  My dialect would pronounce it
> <HOz>. 
>
> In the modifictions I made last night, I realy did very little
other
> than try to space out the characters close to where they were in
your
> early version...  I reshaped a couple of the letters to look
a little
> more like the Read handbook, but not many.  I still do
not have the
> spacing correct... Using the font freeware I downloaded
last night,
> all I could find to really separate the letters was
autometrics. 
> Just expanding the right edge of the characters
alone did not cut
> it.  Unfortunately, the space around a t looks
too big, and to the
> right of a <w> and a <T> looks too
little.  And I do not understand
> why Word seems to do this
differently than MS Paint, for example.   
>
> Yes,
I agree that major changes to the keyboard would not be a good
>
idea.  I read your original comments on wanting to make the font
>
accessable to Shavian writers.  My only significant change is to use
> the <cap> W.  It seemed to be a not very drastic
evolutionary change
> to highlight two of the major changes between
Shavian and
> Quickscript.  It was also in partial answer to a
critique I had seen
> of the use of the left single quote for the wheat
character being
> hard on touch typists.  
>
> I
offered the Junior font as only a small modification from your
> senior
version.  It turns out it was only a retroversion!  How
>
interesting! 
>

>
> In Shavian there are a half
dozen fonts which are variously readable
> and preferable to
individuals.  I believe there is room for parallel
> development of
several Quickscript fonts as well.
>
> Besides, it was fun to
quickly try my hand at mofifying a font... My
> first. 
>
> Rick    
>
> --- In
href="mailto:Read_Alphabet@y">Read_Alphabet@y..., "Jon Zuck" <frimmin@e...> wrote:
> >
You're absolutely right, Rick. Jerome went through quite a bit of
>
evolution,
> > and at first I was quite hesitant to go the distance of
the half-
> letters,
> > and all. However, Paige convinced me,
rightly, that there should be
> a font
> > that could emulate
the full Senior Quickscript capabilities,
> particularly
> >
when presenting its virtues to the Shavian community, which already
> had
a
> > non-cursive Shavian font.
> >
> > I've
uploaded to this group a copy of the poster of the Lord's
> Prayer
which
> > I uploaded a few hours after my initial upload of Jerome. You
can
> see the
> > difference: Junior Quickscriptish, very
easy-to-read, etc.
> >
> > The thing is that there are really
three Shavian alphabets: Shavian,
> > Junior,and Senior.  I think
most people who are not adverse to
> cursive
> > writing :-)
will eventually find Senior the more preferable one for
>
personal
> > handwriting, which is the most practical use for a
semi-private
> alphabet
> > that only a handful of people can
read. But for the computer, in
> English, we
> > usually only
use cursive fonts for art, titles, special emphasis,
> and the
> > feeling of a "personal touch."  On the other hand, many languages
> of world
> > use connected, cursive letters: Hindi, Bengali,
Arabic, Aramaic. I
> felt
> > after much correspondence with
Paige that Read was clearly touting
> the more
> > cursive
capabilities of Senior QA, which should connect.
> >
> > But
thanks for giving us again a Junior font.  It is more legible,
>
more
> > suitable for screen.
> >
> > As long as all
there's interest in all three alphabets, fonts for
> all three
> > should be avail. My only concern is the minor changes to the
>
mapping.  We
> > don't need three mappings. I think a Read-based
mapping is
> desireable, but
> > on the other hand so is
backward compatibility to Shavian--not so
> much to
> > lure
them over, but to use their transliteration programs, which is
> why
I
> > kept it in Jerome. (Bad as their mapping is, the fact that they
> created a
> > standard and built upon it is great.)
> >
> > BTW, I realized that my key to the Second Shaw Alphabet,
originally
> posted
> > to the Shavian group wasn't on the files
in this group and the
> Shavian's
> > copy was corrupted. 
I fixed it and posted it to both.
> >
> >
> >
Shalom v'Tovah,
> >
> > Jon
> >
href="http://surf.to/frimmin">http://surf.to/frimmin
> >
> > It is more necessary to love much than to think much;
> >
always do that which impels you most to love.
> >
> >         --St. Teresa of Avila, The
Interior Castle
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From:
"geoflyfisher" <geoflyfisher@y...>
> > To:
<Read_Alphabet@y...>
> >
Sent: Monday, February 25, 2002 11:16 AM
> > Subject: [Read_Alphabet]
Re: Macbeth
> >
> >
> > > Two thoughts on Jerome
and computer typing in quickscript:
> > >
> > > I have
only recently begun to read Shavian and Quickscript.  I
>
enjoy
> > > some of the advantages of both.  Read's extension
of abreviations
> and
> > > abreviated words in Quickscript
seem wonderful.  However, I find
> the
> > > small
"curleys" in the type version of Jerome hard on my eyes.
> > >
> > > I really appreciate the hard work done on Jerome, but
believe
> > > Quickscript readers could also do with a font that
does not look
> like
> > > penmanship.
> > >
> > > >From reading Read's booklet on Quickscript, it
appears that most
> of
> > > the half letter and joinings
were instituted to make writing with
> a
> > > pen easier,
not reading easier.  Much like script penmanship, I
> > >
believe that most of them detract from the readability of the text
> > > when the text is in an electronic version.  (BTW, I gave up on
> script
> > > writing in the seventh grade about 36 years
ago and have been
> > > printing ever since so that my handwriting
can be easily read.  I
> use
> > > the computer to write
letters for the same reason.)
> > >
> > > I can not
imagine wanting to read a font on the computer which
> > > attempts
to mimic script...  I know they exist, but to prefer this
> > >
for everyday reading!  No thanks.
> > >
> > > I
have been thinking along two lines.
> > >
> > > First,
is there already a version of Quickscript True Type font
> which
> > > looks more like the Junior Quickscript of Read's manual?  If not,
> I
> > > may invest a little time and come up with
one.  I think it could
> > > improve readability in the way
that ghoti and lionspaw are very
> > > readable Shavian
scripts.
> > >
> > > Second, is there a way to program
the keyboard interface to scan
> for
> > > combination
letters other than shift, ctl and alt?  I recently
> worked
> > > on a 7 key keyboard that used "chord fingerings"  for
letters. 
> Chord
> > > fingerings seem like a natural
for phonetic languages like
> > > Quickscript.  It is easy
enough to remember cap T for "theater"
> but
> > > cap Y for
"oil"??  Would it not be nice to just press the o and i
> > >
keys?  The computer would run the following algorhythm when you
> > > pressed the o key... hmmm... o key, must be an o, ... no the i
> key is
> > > also pressed must be an "oil"  now wait
for the next letter press.
> > >
> > > I have not worked
the keyboard interface to see if this kind of
> chord
> > >
keying could be instituted within the present operating systems or
> > > not.  Any computer programmmers with feedback?
> > >
> > > Rick
> > >
> > >
> > > --- In
size=2>Read_Alphabet@y..., "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@c...>
>
wrote:
> > > > I have attached an example of Junior and Senior
Quikscript to
> this
> > > > post.  I had to use an
attachment because I got sick of Windows
> > > crashing
> > > > all the time and switched to using Linux for my operating
>
system.
> > > I am
> > > > running Windows 98 in a
window under Linux.  I haven't figured
> out
> > >
how
> > > > to get Jerome into the Linux side of my computer
yet.  (I'm not
> even
> > > > sure its possible since
it is a truetype font.)
> > > >
> > > > Paige
Gabhart
> > >
> > >

from this group, send an email to:
> > >
href="mailto:Read_Alphabet-unsubscribe@e">Read_Alphabet-unsubscribe@e...

> > >

> > > Your use of
Yahoo! Groups is subject to
